results.content: Handwritten lectures are extremely poor; both terrible penmanship and hand-waving of topic. PowerPoint or Visio charts should replace these. As well, explanation of, for example, what a ReSTful service is was woeful. There was no rigor and will lead learners down a wrong path. Also, the Flask section, should have shown more since it's foundational. The course has potential to be very good, but things need to be cleaned up and done more professionally and comprehensively.
results.content_html: Handwritten lectures are extremely poor; both terrible penmanship and hand-waving of topic. PowerPoint or Visio charts should replace these. As well, explanation of, for example, what a ReSTful service is was woeful. There was no rigor and will lead learners down a wrong path. Also, the Flask section, should have shown more since it's foundational. The course has potential to be very good, but things need to be cleaned up and done more professionally and comprehensively.

results.content:
Here is my latest review:
There are a few things that maybe aren't 100% perfect in the course content when it comes to configuration, i.e. that you may have to google and check stack overflow, but its pretty rare and I actually believe being forced to do this really builds your programming skills. I was able to easily just find what i needed either in FAQ or in google, So now I am somewhat grateful :) I feel my skills are better now. Considering how much he actually covers when he walks you through this extremely extensive course, I'm pretty amazed at how much I've learned.

Here was my first review:
it was fine but we had to figure out to install flask with a different command. 

also for some reason I had to remake my virtual image many times because flask kept crashing . Then I finally had it working in the last one. not sure why but I allocated more ram than he suggested when I made my last image.

results.content: I think overall the content is ok. The reason I don't score it higher is for the following reasons. Several of the lectures are unfocused and need to be reshot. There is a lot of copying and pasting code, which besides the fact that copying and pasting code is a bad code smell, it also makes following along very difficult. The section on image recognition is almost useless because once again the instructor is copying pasting code from links on the internet that no longer exist. To compound it, the explanation is not sufficient to understand what your doing. Another annoying fact is the instructor is not replying to posted questions in the Q&A, so your left on your own to figure out your problems. So overall its just ok.
results.content_html: I think overall the content is ok. The reason I don't score it higher is for the following reasons. Several of the lectures are unfocused and need to be reshot. There is a lot of copying and pasting code, which besides the fact that copying and pasting code is a bad code smell, it also makes following along very difficult. The section on image recognition is almost useless because once again the instructor is copying pasting code from links on the internet that no longer exist. To compound it, the explanation is not sufficient to understand what your doing. Another annoying fact is the instructor is not replying to posted questions in the Q&A, so your left on your own to figure out your problems. So overall its just ok.

results.content: This course is exactly what it says it is. If you know python this is for you. It's comprehensive, teaches you multiple technologies interaction with Python and really helps you get around and get things done. Though not for people looking for detailed usage, but if one needs a quick intro and increase their power with Python implementation this is it and its great. All of the most used technologies in one course.

results.content: This course was pretty good. It was helpful for getting started with Flask, Docker, MongoDB, and deploying to AWS. The image recognition lab needs to be updated and I would've liked to have gone more in depth with Flask and maybe build some more complex apps. Also, it really bothered me that he didn't follow HTTP status code conventions.

The image recognition lab needs to be updated and I would've liked to have gone more in depth with Flask and maybe build some more complex apps. Also, it really bothered me that he didn't follow HTTP status code conventions.

results.content: This was a good course to get you going with Docker and APIs.  I like the use of MongoDb as a way to build out the backend.  Working with Postman was a good way to see how things work.  As a more advanced version, it would have been nice to focus on a functional app with web forms, etc.  That would be for an expanded version of the course.  There were some key pieces of code that were left out of the sessions that caused some headaches for me (and others as noticed in the Q&A).
results.content_html: This was a good course to get you going with Docker and APIs. I like the use of MongoDb as a way to build out the backend. Working with Postman was a good way to see how things work. As a more advanced version, it would have been nice to focus on a functional app with web forms, etc. That would be for an expanded version of the course. There were some key pieces of code that were left out of the sessions that caused some headaches for me (and others as noticed in the Q&A).

Having said that, some of the sections contained repetition of work covered in previous sections.  I got the feeling that the tutor either did not plan the videos sufficiently well or did not have a holistic understanding of the content.  This sometimes disturbed or interfered in the rhythm of the learning process.

results.content:
Overall, it was a good course. It gives you some basics on building REST APIs with Flask. The APIs developed here were a little repetitive. It would help more if there would be some complex API building examples (with object, classes, more OOP ) involving more best-practices.
The support is very poor, a lot of questions remain unanswered on the forum.
On balance, this course is a good introductory to Flask, Docker, Docker compose and MongoDB.
results.content_html:
Overall, it was a good course. It gives you some basics on building REST APIs with Flask. The APIs developed here were a little repetitive. It would help more if there would be some complex API building examples (with object, classes, more OOP ) involving more best-practices.
The support is very poor, a lot of questions remain unanswered on the forum.
On balance, this course is a good introductory to Flask, Docker, Docker compose and MongoDB.

results.content:
Disappointing as a whole. Key concepts, like what makes an API RESTful are completely glossed over, a framework (flask_restful) is used to bypass actually designing and understanding a RESTful structure, and it's beyond obvious the instructor is not skilled in Python, or programming for that matter. The "finished" applications are woefully basic services that shouldn't be deployed for security or practical reasons, not to mention bugs in their behavior. They're hacked-together "proof of concept" type projects that you'd expect to be handed in as assignments for an intro college course, not instruction-level applications from a skilled developer.

All-in-all, this gets you tutorial-style basics on how to create basic API services and Dockerize an application as well as a basic AWS deployment and MongoDB features, but all that is free online in higher-quality tutorials with much more knowledgeable instructors.
results.content_html:
Disappointing as a whole. Key concepts, like what makes an API RESTful are completely glossed over, a framework (flask_restful) is used to bypass actually designing and understanding a RESTful structure, and it's beyond obvious the instructor is not skilled in Python, or programming for that matter. The "finished" applications are woefully basic services that shouldn't be deployed for security or practical reasons, not to mention bugs in their behavior. They're hacked-together "proof of concept" type projects that you'd expect to be handed in as assignments for an intro college course, not instruction-level applications from a skilled developer.

All-in-all, this gets you tutorial-style basics on how to create basic API services and Dockerize an application as well as a basic AWS deployment and MongoDB features, but all that is free online in higher-quality tutorials with much more knowledgeable instructors.

results.content:
The Instructor is great and obviously has a lot of knowlege. The course is structured well - scaling from easy and basic ideas up to more complicated. The parts that I think are a problem - Project 7 is outdated - the source code didn't actually work in 2020. Projects 6 and 7 revolve around complicated topics like Natural Language Proccessing and Deep Learning and a lot of time is spent on explaining the packages (tensorflow etc.) at the expense of more explanation about the main topic - that is APIs. There were no advanced examples of databases in MongoDB and section 9 (Deploying to AWS) didn't explain at all why should I use AWS, what EC2 is and why we actually decided to deploy ImageRecognition.
Overall the course was avarage and I think if it was more focused on the main topic it could be a great source of knowlege and wouldn't be so confusing.
results.content_html:

There were no advanced examples of databases in MongoDB and section 9 (Deploying to AWS) didn't explain at all why should I use AWS, what EC2 is and why we actually decided to deploy ImageRecognition.
Overall the course was avarage and I think if it was more focused on the main topic it could be a great source of knowlege and wouldn't be so confusing.

results.content:
What I like most about this course is learning the full loop/cycle of developing fairly large API's (for learning) and deploying these via AWS, using docker and git to push/pull the API's.  These are fundamentals of DevOps and putting all these together was immensely helpful and I'm glad I took the course.  The instructors notes on screen are a bit sketchy but I had no problem with course delivery and other than a few minor aesthetic notes (haha, who likes notes) then I found this course brilliant without being too long and drawn out.
Awesome.

results.content:
I've changed my review from 4 stars because as the course has progressed I've not been impressed. There are numerous problems with this course:

1. The Docker aspect of the course is so basic it could be covered in a 2 minute demo
2.  The instructors handwritten notes are illegible
3. The instructors attention to detail in his Python code is very poor
4. The instructor clearly has little knowledge of HTTP error codes
5. The "deep dive" into MongoDB is just spoken at you, with any interesting details about the tool simply being read off the slides and not elaborated on at all
6. There is no hint of any proper authentication or security with any of the APIs
7. No tests are implemented
8. There is no where near enough exploration of what Flask-RESTful can do, the instructor again sticks to the very basics
9. The projects are very repetitive
10.  The exploration of ML libraries like Spacy and Tensorflow is again, very basic

I wanted to learn how to build and deploy production grade apps based on the title of the course. On several occasions the instructor says "this is something you might use in real life" but the projects are very amateur and do not cover anything you would not find on the first page of the docs of each tool. The title is click-bait, full of buzz words to get you buy the course. It's not worth it
results.content_html:

10. The exploration of ML libraries like Spacy and Tensorflow is again, very basic

On several occasions the instructor says "this is something you might use in real life" but the projects are very amateur and do not cover anything you would not find on the first page of the docs of each tool. The title is click-bait, full of buzz words to get you buy the course. It's not worth it

results.content:
Really cool course, like most other ppl here, I have taken other tutorials and, sure enough, halfway thru I would get errors and get stuck. My code would be identical to the tutorial but not work.
I just hit the 50% mark of this course and I ran into a couple of hiccups, but the instructor also ran into the same issues and troubleshoot them on the go.

As constructive criticism, the MongoDB module was very long and tedious. We cover 45 minutes of Mongo tutorial for literally 1 function in the app itself.

I am overall very happy, great job and thanks for putting out this content so the likes of me can learn from it.

Thanks

results.content: The professor understands the various steps and processes, subprocess involved in communication across networks.  I have a Master of Science in I.T. and took networking, security and enterprise architecture classes including standard system analysis, uml, modeling and frameworks for such things as object oriented programming and enterprise database systems to replace stovepiped systems.  Coding is something I do on my own in http, html, and javascript.  Basically I code in website environment but also learned scripting which is a context for all c languages.  Scripting and connecting back end to front end is a subprocess of the Graphical User Interface or portal which one uses to administer a web page or just view it.  Without understanding front and back end principles, get and post, and http, one will feel like conceptually they don't really know what is under the hood.  This course is masterful at this point in depicting what one needs to understand about the backend of a program, a portal or a content management system.

I have a Master of Science in I.T. and took networking, security and enterprise architecture classes including standard system analysis, uml, modeling and frameworks for such things as object oriented programming and enterprise database systems to replace stovepiped systems. Coding is something I do on my own in http, html, and javascript. Basically I code in website environment but also learned scripting which is a context for all c languages. Scripting and connecting back end to front end is a subprocess of the Graphical User Interface or portal which one uses to administer a web page or just view it. Without understanding front and back end principles, get and post, and http, one will feel like conceptually they don't really know what is under the hood. This course is masterful at this point in depicting what one needs to understand about the backend of a program, a portal or a content management system.

results.content: Overall the course is good in that it gives several examples on developing an API as well as specific types of API's that are unique and relevant.  There are a couple of items that I mark down that make this a good course vs a great course.  First, my number one complaint for these programming courses is the tremendous amount of time that we need to spend watching the instructor type.  We are given the source code, we should be reviewing the program and getting an understanding of what it does vs waiting for the instructor to finish typing.  Additionally, Farouk had mistakes so we watch as he goes through and corrects his typing.  Second item is that Farouk draws the REST schedule, this should be a formatted document that is a handout as part of the section.  The drawing is sloppy, unreadable in some cases and certainly doesn't provide a good take-away.
results.content_html: Overall the course is good in that it gives several examples on developing an API as well as specific types of API's that are unique and relevant. There are a couple of items that I mark down that make this a good course vs a great course. First, my number one complaint for these programming courses is the tremendous amount of time that we need to spend watching the instructor type. We are given the source code, we should be reviewing the program and getting an understanding of what it does vs waiting for the instructor to finish typing. Additionally, Farouk had mistakes so we watch as he goes through and corrects his typing. Second item is that Farouk draws the REST schedule, this should be a formatted document that is a handout as part of the section. The drawing is sloppy, unreadable in some cases and certainly doesn't provide a good take-away.

results.content:
Some basic vbox and linux tutorials are missing. I had to pause the videos too many times to find out how to do certain stuff. Installing Guest Additions to get a normal screen resolution, for example. Downloading the required software and plugins should have been in the first section in one or two videos. Finding out in the middle of the course that you have to install more software, plugins etc is just going backwards. At some point, I had to increase the size of my virutal drive because I ran out of space for some reason. Maybe the latest Ubuntu version is heavier. This resulted in a failed Docker installation, eventually freezing my VM, so I had to uninstall and reinstall the OS and basically redo the whole course to that point. 

The mongoDB section is just too long and theoretical, and the instructor would hang on simple stuff and repeat himself over nothing. It's too simple of a subject to waste an hour of boring slides and bad doodles. Drawing the same table (collection) sketch on every slide multiple times is not professional. I believe a more straight up practical approach of teaching this would have been better. If you do think a theoretical approach is needed, at least leave the doodling out, and stick to just reading the slides (once) without repeating the same thing over and over again. Another solution would be to tell students that already have an idea of what a DB is, that they can skip that section altogether, because practice would be enough after skimming through the syntax once. 

Thanks.
results.content_html:
Some basic vbox and linux tutorials are missing. I had to pause the videos too many times to find out how to do certain stuff. Installing Guest Additions to get a normal screen resolution, for example. Downloading the required software and plugins should have been in the first section in one or two videos. Finding out in the middle of the course that you have to install more software, plugins etc is just going backwards. At some point, I had to increase the size of my virutal drive because I ran out of space for some reason. Maybe the latest Ubuntu version is heavier. This resulted in a failed Docker installation, eventually freezing my VM, so I had to uninstall and reinstall the OS and basically redo the whole course to that point.

The mongoDB section is just too long and theoretical, and the instructor would hang on simple stuff and repeat himself over nothing. It's too simple of a subject to waste an hour of boring slides and bad doodles. Drawing the same table (collection) sketch on every slide multiple times is not professional. I believe a more straight up practical approach of teaching this would have been better. If you do think a theoretical approach is needed, at least leave the doodling out, and stick to just reading the slides (once) without repeating the same thing over and over again. Another solution would be to tell students that already have an idea of what a DB is, that they can skip that section altogether, because practice would be enough after skimming through the syntax once.

Thanks.

results.content_html:
The lecturer often makes mistakes as if the course was taken live without an old plan.
Additionally, functions are introduced without explanation, and the designs are copy-paste and are secondary to each other.
I do not recommend it, waste of time and money

results.content:
The topics chosen for the course were fine.  The course was poor enough that I decided not to finish it, after watching the first few lectures.   Problems:
(1) Audio quality is very poor.
(2) The main language of the course is python, and the author's level of experience was clearly not very high.
(3) The main point of the course is coding RESTful APIs, and while it's probably a bad idea to go into the most technical definition of REST available, there's a happy medium.  The author's definition was very vague.
(4) Other random technical errors, such as claiming that TCP is a text-based protocol.  (HTTP might be, but certainly not TCP.)
results.content_html:

results.content:
The instructor used sketchbook application to write down the lecture material while he was presenting it.   It made many thing verify difficult to read.   This information should be provided in a more professional, readable style

The use of the protocol chart (resources, URL, Method, Parameters, Status Codes) is a good practice....but again... make it more readable

I never got the Similarity API to work.  I had the same problem that was reported by another student 2 months ago.  I download the instructor's resource (source code) files and tried to run the instructor's solution and also got the same error.

The lesson on moving the software from a local machine to an AWS provided machine was filled with so many errors that the instructor finally resolved, but it made this entire lesson extremely confusing.   Now that the instructor knows every step that needs to be completed, he need to re-record this lesson without all of the errors.
results.content_html:

The lesson on moving the software from a local machine to an AWS provided machine was filled with so many errors that the instructor finally resolved, but it made this entire lesson extremely confusing. Now that the instructor knows every step that needs to be completed, he need to re-record this lesson without all of the errors.

Course was okay. Gave a good background of APIs and Flask. I definitely gained knowledge and skills.
However, in the beginning of the course I had a hard time with working on Ubuntu. Also, I ran into a bunch of technical issues throughout the course.
Overall, was a decent course.

results.content:
- It is so good when you move from A to Z. So basic with API charts.
- But some samples don't work with some reasons e.g tensorflow doesn't work with Python 3 (may be need more configuration).
- You should include some exercises and open questions.
- You samples are not good e.g Text-Similiarity is the same as Image-Clarification. Should more type of samples.

results.content:
Course is great, content is great learning a ton!
When working in different windows your font size is extremely hard to read, please make content larger for readability when trying to follow along, especially on a single laptop monitor

When starting out app.py it would be helpful to build out code shells of all the classes and functions that make up the program instead of bouncing around while coding the logic. 

Keep the parts where you cut out debugging process, this is probably the most beneficial part of what you are doing, find a bug and fix it.
Other than this it is very good real world programming scenarios and great job explaining how API's work from scratch

results.content: This is truly a 5 star course. The instructor is EXTREMELY patient and knowledgeable on the subjects and really gives great examples to help you understand terminology and concepts early on in the course. The class also builds up in difficulty so you aren't just thrown into writing difficult functions and being lost trying to keep up...it was really well structured.

The class also builds up in difficulty so you aren't just thrown into writing difficult functions and being lost trying to keep up...it was really well structured.

results.content:
I love the course because instructor is teaching step by step with full support of coding part, extra installation were covering as well, plus focusing on implementation without complicating the task. I was following the course material and didn't get any blocks to trouble shoot my code. It likes win win for me.
Thank you!!!
